repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Might be jumping the gun on this (not very critical), but it was low-cost to just post it.

It replaces the lost recursive functionality from #25118 and mainly it would just exist to nudge people away from coming up with something worse.

comment_data.body: I don't think a "default" for a key makes sense here
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2323,6 +2323,18 @@ vim.tbl_values({t})                                         *vim.tbl_values()*
     Return: ~
         (list) List of values
 
+vim.traverse({node}, {key}, {visitor})                        *vim.traverse()*
+    Visits children of a node recursively, applying the provided visitor
+    function
+
+    Parameters: ~
+      • {node}     (table) The root node to visit
+      • {key}      nil|string|fun(node: Node): Node[] How to find the children

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
        local comments = {}
        vim.traverse(
```
A bit pedantic,  but I like code snippets to be copy&pasteable, if possible :)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2323,6 +2323,30 @@ vim.tbl_values({t})                                         *vim.tbl_values()*
     Return: ~
         (list) List of values
 
+vim.traverse({tree}, {key}, {visitor})                        *vim.traverse()*
+    Traverses any tree-like object defined by `key`, calling the provided
+    `visitor` on each descendant.
+
+    Example: >lua
+
+        vim.traverse(

@@ -2323,6 +2323,30 @@ vim.tbl_values({t})                                         *vim.tbl_values()*
     Return: ~
         (list) List of values
 
+vim.traverse({tree}, {key}, {visitor})                        *vim.traverse()*
+    Traverses any tree-like object defined by `key`, calling the provided
+    `visitor` on each descendant.
+
+    Example: >lua
+
+        vim.traverse(

comment_regular_data.body:
>  although this means the optional arg isn't last.

General API guideline is:
* mandatory arguments are positional
* optional arguments are keyword-style (i.e., through a final `opts` table)

Just going by the documentation, that looks to be rather specific to treesitter -- too much to be under the general `vim` API.

I suspect that the function itself is much more general, and would recommend that the documentation reflect that ("traverse an arbitrary tree defined by ..."), with treesitter tree used as an example.

> > although this means the optional arg isn't last.
> 
> General API guideline is:
> 
> * mandatory arguments are positional
> * optional arguments are keyword-style (i.e., through a final `opts` table)

Need to amend that. The callback should always be last. `opts` can be penultimate. It's much more readable if the callback is the final arg, otherwise one must travel to the end of the callback body to see if additional args were passed.
In this case, we can just make `key` mandatory, though; I don't see much benefit of allowing (explicit) `nil` for a (treesitter specific) default.

> Just going by the documentation, that looks to be rather specific to treesitter

Reworded.

Technically, you can use `vim.traverse` on graphs as well, provided you check for revisitation (it just so happens that trees are exactly the set of graphs with no revisitation)

> we can just make key mandatory

Good, that solves the dilemma. Updated.

I also removed the generic since it doesn't seem to work well with the doc pipeline (or Lua in general)
I think a concrete example would be helpful then, though?

> > > although this means the optional arg isn't last.
> > 
> > 
> > General API guideline is:
> > 
> > * mandatory arguments are positional
> > * optional arguments are keyword-style (i.e., through a final `opts` table)
> 
> Need to amend that. The callback should always be last. `opts` can be penultimate. It's much more readable if the callback is the final arg, otherwise one must travel to the end of the callback body to see if additional args were passed.

@justinmk mind adding that to `:h dev-api`? These things are hard to remember later on.

> I think a concrete example would be helpful then, though?

Sure, added

title: feat(shared.lua): `vim.traverse`
